Marine.Action: Looks after Lenihan, a new and inexperienced marine, acknowledging his need for guidance.
Encourages Lenihan during a nervous moment, including him in a toast despite reluctance.
Imlay grabs hold of Lenihan, helping him forward despite his injury.
Nantz shoves Imlay away and puts a boot into his chest, rejecting help and showing aggression.
Imlay helps Lenihan forward despite Lenihan struggling and breathing hard.
Nantz insists every man carry his weight and pushes Imlay away, showing intolerance for perceived weakness.
Nantz shoves Imlay onto his ass and puts a boot into his chest, showing aggressive leadership but potentially poor judgment or lack of empathy.
Nantz motivates Lenihan to save the wounded Imlay despite Lenihan's weakness, pushing him to act beyond his limits.
Lenihan, though struggling and stumbling, manages to carry Imlay up the hill, demonstrating determination and capability under pressure.
Sgt. Nantz insists on pushing forward despite Lenihan's twisted ankle, demonstrating confidence and a no-quit attitude.
Correggio acknowledges Lenihan's injury and hesitates, showing caution but also some doubt about pushing forward.
Sgt. Nantz orders a saline bag and ankle taping to treat Lenihan quickly, showing practical field medical knowledge and decisiveness.
Lenihan falls and yells in pain, unable to continue, showing physical limitation but no indication of incompetence.
Follows orders promptly and prepares to draw weapons when alerted by 1st Sgt. Roy.
Stops running immediately upon hearing sirens and obeys command to hold position.
Nantz accepts deployment orders despite being burnt out and resigned, showing willingness to fulfill duty under pressure.
Nantz shows concern about losing paperwork, indicating attention to detail.
Nantz asks questions to understand the situation, demonstrating situational awareness and engagement.
Listens attentively during the briefing and gears up promptly when ordered, showing readiness and focus.
Engages in nervous small talk while waiting for weapons, indicating some anxiety but maintaining composure.
Moves quickly and efficiently to board the helicopter, follows orders promptly.
Shows nervousness and uncertainty during flight, shouting over the noise.
Blanches at the order to level the area, showing hesitation or discomfort with the mission's harshness.
Questions the captain about civilians possibly stuck behind the line, demonstrating awareness and concern for non-combatants.
Setting up sand-bagged machine gun nests and mortars, organizing defensive positions under fire.
Waving civilians, including a little girl, to safety amidst chaos.
Correggio pets the dog, trying to comfort it.
Sgt. Nantz dismisses private Simmons' question caustically.
Maintains alertness and readiness as squad moves cautiously through smoke-filled street, aiming weapons at potential threats.
Sgt. Nantz dismisses Private Simmons' question curtly but effectively, maintaining command control and focus.
Kerns quickly identifies and calls out contact, demonstrating situational awareness.
Correggio attempts to calm Kerns and the dog, showing emotional intelligence and leadership under stress.
Squad momentarily reacts with nervous chuckles and slight tension when dog appears, indicating some unease but controlled response.
No clear negative indicators of incompetence or poor decision-making in this excerpt.
Kerns breaks formation, sprints down the side street firing, causing the squad to lose discipline and follow him impulsively.
SGT. Nantz immediately calls out the loss of discipline and orders the Marines to hold position and think, emphasizing mission focus and survival.
LT. Martinez supports maintaining discipline and mission focus, ordering to hold fire and stay on course.
Kerns appears panicked and breath ragged after firing at the alien, showing signs of stress and loss of composure.
Fires back into thick smoke despite poor visibility and increasing enemy ferocity.
Mottola works the radio trying to remain calm under pressure.
Lenihan panics after being hit by corrosive liquid, showing distress and lack of composure.
Imlay immediately assists Lenihan by removing his helmet and providing support.
Martinez checks the map for escape routes while under fire.
Follows orders to retreat under heavy fire, maintains squad cohesion during chaotic enemy attack.
Freezes under fire (Kerns), showing momentary hesitation.
Quickly recovers from ambush, executes a counterattack led by Nantz, showing tactical awareness.
Protects a fellow marine (Correggio protecting Kerns), demonstrating situational awareness and teamwork.
Sustains injury but continues fighting, showing resilience and determination.
Adukwu wraps Grayston's wounded arm and lights his cigarette, sharing a small moment of kindness and camaraderie.
Correggio checks on Kerns, asking if he is okay, showing concern for a fellow marine.
Lays down an awesome barrage with powerful SAWs, covering the retreat effectively.
Barges through the front door of the house despite chaos, showing decisiveness and aggression.
Sweaty, bleeding, scared, showing signs of fear and stress but still continuing to fight.
Private Simmons panics and questions the situation loudly, showing lack of composure.
Sergeant Nantz commands to 'stow that shit' and orders to watch the yard and secure the back, showing leadership and confidence.
Kerns stares back like a deer in headlights, showing fear and lack of confidence.
Nantz takes initiative to go for Lenihan despite danger, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Nantz efficiently orders a medevac and communicates clearly with team.
Martinez admits to leading the unit into an ambush, showing self-awareness but also a tactical error.
Mottola slaps Imlay in the helmet to get his attention and reinforce the order to stay quiet and close, showing leadership and clear communication.
Lenihan cautiously enters a dark garage, uses available cover, and attempts radio communication despite risks, demonstrating situational awareness and resourcefulness.
Lenihan panics when something bangs against the garage, eyes going wide, indicating a momentary lapse in composure under pressure.
Holds M-16 tightly and remains very still despite fear and loss of blood, showing focus and discipline under stress.
Moves cautiously, trying not to make noise while searching through the garage, demonstrating stealth and awareness.
Fires wildly when window crashes in, indicating panic and loss of control.
Fumbles for the door handle and falls while trying to escape the garage, showing clumsiness under pressure.
Despite panic, quickly reacts to the alien rising from the pool by firing and successfully blasts it back into the water.
Loads another magazine quickly and edges toward the pool to engage the enemy.
Raises rifle to fire more rounds at the alien despite nervousness.
Gets wounded and separated from unit, requiring rescue and medevac.
Reports clearly and succinctly about the status of their unit under extreme stress.
Admits that everyone else in their unit is dead or missing, indicating a failure to maintain unit cohesion or survive.
Sgt. Nantz quickly assesses the situation, locates civilians including children, and moves decisively to secure them.
Cpl. Stavrou asserts authority to make room on the medevac helicopter, successfully negotiating with the crewman under pressure.
Pvt. Imlay reports more wounded than initially called in, showing situational awareness.
Imlay kneels by the kids, who look devastated by the day's events.
Nantz refuses to get close to the men, stating 'don't ask me to get close to them.'
Follows orders promptly to secure the perimeter and set up observation posts, showing readiness and discipline.
Looks stunned and breathing hard, indicating shock and possible momentary disorientation.
Maintains vigilance by covering doors and hallways despite the changed nature of the fight, demonstrating adaptability.
Shows signs of fear and desperation (e.g., Nantz's solemn stare), which may undermine confidence and effectiveness.
Wets a rag and gently wipes dust and dirt from the kids' faces.
Responds to a child's hug with initial discomfort but then hugs back and smiles reassuringly.
Reassures a child by promising not to leave them.
Imlay comforts scared children by cleaning their faces and responding reassuringly to their fears, showing empathy and calm under pressure.
Imlay initially looks uncomfortable when hugged by a child but quickly recovers and responds appropriately.
Adukwu immediately responds to Nantz's order to bring the medical kit, showing readiness and promptness.
Mottola reports the radio communication failure clearly and promptly to Nantz.
The marines on the rooftop maintain silent vigilance despite exhaustion, exchanging a clear 'all-clear' sign.
Correggio confidently reports 'We're clear up here' over the radio, indicating situational awareness and communication skills.
Correggio and Kerns share a moment of laughter despite the dire situation, showing emotional resilience but not directly related to competence.
Kerns doubts his own ability ('I thought I could handle it...'), indicating some self-doubt and questioning competence.
Kerns acknowledges Sergeant Nantz's skill and leadership in saving them during an ambush ('He knows what he's doing').
Nantz confidently questions Michele about her readiness and approaches the alien body with others, showing leadership and composure.
Michele expresses uncertainty ('I was more sure two minutes ago'), indicating a momentary lapse in confidence.
Takes responsibility for decision to move fast despite risks, showing concern for civilians' safety.
Decides to retrieve abandoned bus to help transport civilians, demonstrating resourcefulness and care.
Makes decisions authoritatively without consulting others, potentially limiting input.
Works diligently to wire a school bus despite distractions, showing focus and skill.
Ignores urgent warning about enemy scout, delaying reaction.
Nantz pulls his knife and kills the alien by targeting a vital organ with precision.
Mottola reports a breach promptly, showing situational awareness.
Nantz suggests gathering civilians in the gym, demonstrating tactical thinking.
Stavrou attempts to start the bus but fails, then quickly drops below the wheel again, showing persistence but limited success.
Smiles briefly and politely asks a little girl for her ponytail holder to help with the situation.
Focuses on tactical instructions and quickly leaves the bus without further comforting the children or others.
Realizes the enemy is tracking their radio signals and orders all radios and cell phones to be turned off to avoid detection.
Quickly takes the ponytail holder from a child to use as an improvised tool or antenna for the radio, showing resourcefulness.
Instructs the lieutenant to take the kids and leave if anything happens, demonstrating leadership and foresight.
Runs out of the bus alone with the radio toward a gas station, potentially exposing himself to danger without backup.
Wraps pony tail holder around radio to keep button pressed, sending constant signal while moving tactically behind cover.
Loads grenade launcher and fires grenade at alien aircraft, successfully hitting gas pump and causing massive fireball to hit the craft.
Nantz quickly assesses the crashed alien drone, identifies it as unmanned, and deduces the presence of a command and control center, showing situational awareness and intelligence.
Nantz runs back onto the bus promptly after checking the crash site, maintaining focus on the mission and team safety.
Nantz accepts Martinez's reprimand about teamwork and agrees to follow orders, demonstrating discipline and adaptability.
Nantz voices concern about taking the freeway due to exposure risk, showing caution and tactical thinking.
Nantz's concern about the freeway is overridden by Martinez's decision, indicating a possible lack of influence or assertiveness in command decisions.
Follows orders promptly, sets up perimeter, helps civilians evacuate under fire.
Looks unsure about what to do next (Martinez unsure what to do).
Nantz confidently commands his men to fix bayonets and prepare to repel the enemy despite being vastly outnumbered, demonstrating leadership and tactical awareness.
Imlay effectively uses binoculars to spot and report enemy movement accurately and promptly.
Stavrou carefully negotiates a fractured off-ramp and secures the area, signaling 'All Clear' to his cover, showing situational awareness and caution.
Kerns picks up Kirsten and helps get children down the off-ramp safely, showing care and protection.
Encourages others by saying 'It's gonna be scary but we can do it, okay?'
Kerns takes a breath, encourages himself and others by saying 'It's gonna be scary but we can do it, okay?'
Kerns and Adukwu race away carrying the girls to safety under heavy fire, showing calm and effective leadership.
Kerns helps Hector angle down the off-ramp safely, demonstrating skill and care under pressure.
Rincon pulls the injured Mottola toward safety despite danger, showing determination and presence of mind.
Rincon quickly adapts by picking up Mottola's rifle and asks for instructions, demonstrating resourcefulness and willingness to learn under pressure.
Rincon carefully aims and fires the rifle after brief instruction, showing ability to perform under stress despite being scared.
Rincon shows fear but remains resolute, indicating some nervousness but overall competent behavior.
Rincon fires to save Adukwu from an alien attack.
Adukwu shouts a warning to Rincon to keep fighting, showing concern and encouragement.
Adukwu immediately provides first aid to Rincon after he is hit, showing care and quick response.
Nantz encourages Kerns to come along and expresses trust in fighting next to him, showing camaraderie and friendliness.
Rincon fires accurately and saves Adukwu from an alien attack.
Adukwu quickly applies QuickClot to Rincon's wounds, showing medical skill and presence of mind.
Nantz quickly assesses the situation, requests smoke canisters, and organizes cover with Kerns, demonstrating tactical awareness and leadership.
Rincon turns to fire too late and is hit, indicating a momentary lapse in situational awareness.
Ensures Kerns is with him while moving between cars during combat.
Focuses on tactical actions and combat effectiveness without showing interpersonal warmth in this excerpt.
Unscrews the fuse from the smoke grenade, pulls the pin, flips the spoon off, and uses it to ignite the gas tank, creating a wall of flame to funnel enemies into a kill zone.
Coordinates with fellow marines to lay cover fire and execute a tactical retreat behind cover after igniting explosives.
Demonstrates situational awareness by ensuring squad members are with him and holding the line with others against overwhelming enemy numbers.
Martinez stays behind to cover retreat despite being mortally wounded, ensuring others can escape safely.
Martinez pushes Nantz away to stay and cover, showing self-sacrifice and concern for comrades.
Martinez stays behind to cover the retreat despite being severely wounded, showing leadership and commitment under fire.
Martinez orders the men to pull back and gives clear commands even while injured, demonstrating control and tactical awareness.
Martinez pushes Nantz away to stay and cover the retreat, risking his own life to protect others, indicating confidence and responsibility.

Martinez pulls a smoke canister, unscrews the fuse, and drops it into the gas tank of the bus to create a massive explosion that kills all the aliens surrounding him, sacrificing himself to save others.
Nantz quickly takes charge after Martinez's sacrifice, organizing the marines and civilians and giving clear orders to package the wounded for transport and move forward.
Marines carry the kids to safety, showing care and protection.
Nantz pulls blankets to cover injured Rincon, providing comfort.
Nantz orders to tighten the place down and focus on communications, showing leadership but no explicit warmth.

Carries children to safety amidst chaos, helps carry injured Rincon, covers Rincon with blankets, organizes shelter and security in the sporting goods store, instructs others to prepare for bomb impact, attempts to establish hardline communications.
Promises to get Rincon's son out and accepts Rincon's trust with a handshake.
Unable to meet Hector's gaze, showing emotional struggle but no direct comfort.
Silent and at a loss when Rincon refuses to be taken, showing hesitation but no confrontation.
Nantz promises to get Rincon's son out and takes his hand, showing commitment despite the heavy emotional burden.
Nantz looks at the clock and hears the bomb countdown but shows a blank expression and is silent when Rincon refuses to be taken, indicating hesitation or emotional overwhelm.
Harris attempts to communicate with his loved one via computer, quickly typing and responding to messages under stress.
Fails to maintain internet connection; computer freezes and message fails to send.
Stavrou orders marines to get away from windows and protect civilians, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Marines stiffen and raise rifles immediately upon spotting hostiles, showing readiness and alertness.
Move silently through the store and slip out the back door when the front is compromised, demonstrating tactical awareness and discipline.
Follow Sergeant Nantz's orders to blow something up, indicating willingness to act decisively on commands.
No hesitation or panic shown despite alien breach, maintaining composure.
Follows orders promptly, takes cover under cars with civilians during alien attack, helps protect children by pulling them under cover.
Moves in formation surrounding civilians, maintains situational awareness and group cohesion.
No hesitation or confusion shown when the alien horde appears, reacts quickly and effectively.
Moves cautiously with rifles up, hustles civilians inside when safe, secures doors and windows, follows orders to get under cover promptly.
No indication of hesitation or confusion despite devastating situation; maintains discipline and focus.
Presents a medallion to Hector in honor of his father, offers encouragement and shares a story to uplift him.
Places a hand on Hector's shoulder reassuringly before moving out.
Sgt. Nantz organizes the marines, assigns roles clearly, and motivates Hector by explaining the significance of the medallion and the motto, showing leadership and confidence.
Sgt. Nantz calmly assesses the situation, ensures security before moving forward, and plans to retrieve ammo, demonstrating situational awareness and tactical skill.
Rifles pockets of fallen comrades to scavenge ammo, showing resourcefulness under pressure.
Quickly identifies and secures an intact LAV-25 armored personnel carrier, recognizing its tactical value.
Assigns roles efficiently, with Nantz delegating driving to Stavrou and positioning Imlay to the control tower for better situational awareness.
Correggio expresses concern about vehicles being targets, but Nantz confidently counters with tactical reasoning, demonstrating leadership and understanding of assets.
SGT. Nantz quickly assesses the situation using binoculars and a map, identifies an alternate extraction site, and organizes an evacuation plan under pressure.
SGT. Nantz reassures PVT. Imlay with confidence, showing leadership and calm under stress.
Marines protectively surround civilians and efficiently move them into the LAV, demonstrating discipline and care.
Nantz takes initiative to communicate clearly and promptly over the radio, requesting evacuation and providing precise information about their location and personnel.
Nantz orders the driver to use thermal sight and no lights, demonstrating tactical awareness and caution in a dangerous environment.
Nantz immediately mans the machine gun turret, ready to defend the group, showing preparedness and skill.
Stavrou drives carefully through wrecked abandoned cars, gripping the wheel tightly and focusing tensely through the thermal sight scope.
Stavrou slams the brakes immediately upon spotting a massive crater blocking the street, preventing a potential accident.
Nantz scans the sky while gripping the machine gun, preparing for incoming alien drone aircraft and giving clear commands to the team.
Imlay opens fire on the alien drones with the Bushmaster chain gun as ordered, showing readiness and aggression.
Targets and fires the Bushmaster effectively, hitting and destroying multiple alien aircraft under pressure.
Maintains situational awareness and communicates threats clearly (e.g., 'I got it', responding to SGT. Nantz).
No hesitation or confusion shown despite explosions and incoming threats.
Helps load civilians into the helicopter efficiently under fire.
Scrambles onto the helicopter quickly as it powers up, showing situational awareness and urgency.
Observes and questions the sudden loss of helicopter power and altitude, showing alertness and concern.
Puts a hand on Hector's shoulder and offers reassurance with a smile, saying 'They'll get you safe' and 'See you soon, buddy.'
Leads frightened and confused marines to rappel down into danger, showing resolve but not explicitly addressing their fear or offering comfort beyond orders.
Suggests landing despite risks and proposes rappelling down to recon the area, showing initiative and tactical thinking.
Leads marines to rappel down one after another, demonstrating leadership and confidence under pressure.
Encourages and reassures others before dropping out of the chopper to fight, showing resolve and decisiveness.
SGT. Nantz expresses sincere grief for fallen marines and honors their memory to motivate the group.
SGT. Nantz openly admits vulnerability and the possibility of dying, emphasizing unity and mutual support.
SGT. Nantz encourages and inspires the marines by appealing to shared identity and duty.
SGT. Nantz motivates the marines with a clear, confident speech emphasizing duty and unity, inspiring them to continue fighting despite hopelessness.
SGT. Nantz acknowledges the risks and potential for death honestly, showing realistic assessment and leadership.
CPL. Correggio expresses doubt and frustration, questioning the decision to get off the chopper and showing emotional reaction that could undermine group cohesion.
Nantz efficiently gathers necessary gear including a combat shotgun, radio, and laser target device, showing preparedness and tactical awareness.
Stavrou drives the LAV aggressively through enemy lines, effectively using the vehicle's armor to mow down aliens, demonstrating skillful and confident combat driving.
Nantz calmly directs Stavrou to reverse and continue engaging enemies, showing clear-headed leadership under fire.
Follows Sergeant Nantz's orders promptly and moves out of the LAV to cover each other's advance while scanning for targets.
Sweats and shows signs of stress in a tense, power-loss situation but continues to maintain formation and readiness.
Leads team cautiously and silently, uses knife skillfully to open door, assigns guards to watch backs, moves forward with gun ready, conserves flashlight battery when electronic devices fail.
Signals teammate to stay put and cautiously approaches the source of light, showing situational awareness.
Runs back and calls teammate to run when spotting a hostile alien, demonstrating quick decision-making under pressure.
Fires shotgun repeatedly to slow down the pursuing alien, using available resources effectively despite being in a confined space.
Shotgun runs dry, leaving him vulnerable and in darkness, indicating a limitation in resource management or preparation.
Nantz takes initiative to identify a critical enemy asset and plans to destroy it, coordinating a complex strike under pressure.
Nantz calmly communicates with his team, assesses the situation, and motivates them to hold the line despite limited resources.
The marines acknowledge the difficulty but maintain focus and morale, showing readiness to execute a dangerous mission.
Despite a severe ankle injury and being trapped under rubble, Nantz manages to free himself, hobble to his feet, and lead the marines out through a dangerous stairway filled with rubble.

After emerging from rubble and taking cover, Nantz quickly sets up the laser designator and takes protective measures by covering it with his flack jacket, showing tactical awareness and resourcefulness.
Forms a perimeter around the laser and opens fire on the aliens, maintaining defensive formation under pressure.
Nantz picks targets efficiently, switches weapons when rifle runs dry, and continues to engage enemies despite being outnumbered and under fire.
Nantz struggles to re-aim the laser after an explosion knocks it away, showing persistence and quick recovery.
Marines fight nearly back to back in a small circle around the laser, demonstrating coordinated defense and situational awareness.
Kerns is hit and thrown to the ground but quickly gets back up and continues firing despite injury.
Correggio spins just in time to fire repeatedly and take down a rushing alien.
Stavrou uses rifle butt to smash an alien and then puts numerous rounds into it, showing adaptability and effective close combat skills.
Adukwu is knocked to the ground and about to be blasted, no further action shown in excerpt.
Fights cohesively as a unit, following orders to fall back under missile attack while continuing to fire and cover each other.
No individual Marine action detailed; overall behavior shows discipline and tactical awareness under extreme pressure.
Leads men with clear commands and fights alongside them, fostering unity and trust.
Shares a friendly exchange with Correggio, smiling and complimenting him sincerely.
Checks in with squad after battle, ensuring everyone is okay and ready for more.
Moves forward precisely and deadly, fighting as one with the squad, successfully mowing down aliens and causing their retreat.
Stands ready with smoking weapons, prepared for more combat after a tough battle.
Responds immediately and confidently to Sergeant Nantz's leadership and commands.
Nantz expresses pride in his men, telling them they earned the right to call themselves marines.
Responds with a confident and unified battle cry 'HELL!' when ordered to retreat, showing discipline and readiness.
Receives praise from Nantz for earning the right to be called marines, indicating successful performance and capability.

LT. MARTINEZ.Action: Smiles warmly at his wife Anna, shares a tender moment kissing her pregnant belly, and runs back to her before leaving.
Decides quickly to move fast despite risks, takes responsibility for decision.
Uses map to locate FOB and plans route under pressure.
Ignores concerns about bus being a big target and no radio contact, insists on plan without apparent contingency.

SGT. NANTZ.Action: Questions the plan and points out risks (bus as a big target, no radio contact).

CPL. HARRIS.Action: Confidently volunteers to hotwire bus, showing practical skills.

Martinez.Action: Commands Stavrou to get to the Forward Operating Base quickly, showing decisiveness and concern for mission and safety.
Orders Stavrou to get to the Forward Operating Base quickly, showing decisiveness and urgency.
Maintains focus and composure while facing an overwhelming alien armada, coordinating with Nantz.

Rincon.Action: Reassures Mottola with 'It's okay, son. I got you.' and tries to pull him to safety despite danger.
Picks up Mottola's rifle to defend against aliens, showing resolve and protective intent.
